subsection.title: Products and Quotients
subsection.p: In Chapter 7 we learned the first and second laws of exponents, which we use to compute products and quotients of powers.

li.p: To multiply two powers with the same base, we add the exponents and leave the base unchanged. 5^2 \cdot 5^6 = 5^8

To divide two powers with the same base, we subtract the smaller exponent from the larger. If the larger exponent occurs in the numerator, we put the power in the numerator. \dfrac{3^7}{3^2} = 3^5~~~~~~~~\blert{\text{Larger exponentis in the numerator.}}
If the larger exponent occurs in the denominator, we put the power in the denominator. \dfrac{2^3}{2^5} = \dfrac{1}{2^2}~~~~~~~~\blert{\text{Larger exponent is in the denominator.}}

statement.p: Why do we add exponents when we multiply powers with the same base?

answer.p: The exponents tell us how many copies of the base to multiply together.

subsection.p: These laws are expressed in symbols below.

assemblage.p: First Law of Exponents \blert{a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}}

subsection.p: In this Lesson we'll study three more laws of exponents.

subsection.title: Power of a Power

assemblage.title: Third Law of Exponents
assemblage.p: To raise a power to a power, keep the same base and multiply the exponents. In symbols, \blert{(a^m)^n = a^{mn}}

answer.p: (2^3)^3 is larger because it is a product of three copies of (2^3).

subsection.title: Power of a Product
subsection.p: To simplify the expression (2x)^3, we can use the commutative and associative properties of multiplication to write (2x)^3 \amp = (2x)(2x)(2x) \amp = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \amp = 2^3x^3 Thus, to raise a product to a power we can raise each factor to the power. This example illustrates the following rule.

assemblage.title: Fourth Law of Exponents
assemblage.p: To raise a product to a power, raise each factor to the power. In symbols, \blert{(ab)^n = a^nb^n}

md.mrow: (-xy^3)^4 \amp = (-x)^4(y^3)^4 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Raise each factor to the fourth power;}}
\amp = x^4y^{12} \amp \amp \blert{\text{apply the third lasw of exponents.}}

warning.p: Note the difference between the two expressions 3a^2 and (3a)^2: 3a^2~~~~\text{cannot be simplified, but} (3a)^2 = 3^2a^2 = 9a^2 In the expression 3a^2, only the factor a is squared, but in (3a)^2 both 3 and a are squared.

statement.p: Explain why we cannot use the fourth law of exponents to simpify (a+b)^3 as a^3+b^3.

answer.p: Because a+b is a sum, not a product.

subsection.title: Power of a Quotient

assemblage.title: Fifth Law of Exponents
assemblage.p: To raise a quotient to a power, raise both the numerator and the denominator to the power. In symbols, \blert{\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}}

p.m: \left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)^5 = \dfrac{x^5}{y^5} ~~~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Raise top and bottom to the fifth power.}}

md.mrow: \left(\dfrac{2}{y^2}\right)^3 \amp = \dfrac{2^3}{(y^2)^3} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Raise top and bottom to the third power.}}
\amp =\dfrac{2^3}{y^{2 \cdot 3}} = \dfrac{8}{y^6} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply the third law of exponents to the denominator.}}

subsection.title: Using the Laws of Exponents
subsection.p: We can use the laws of exponents along with the order of operations to simplify algebraic expressions. The five laws of exponents are stated together below. All of the laws are valid when the base is not equal to zero and when the exponents m and n are positive integers.

statement.p: In Example 5, why did we start by simplifying (3xy^2)^4?

answer.p: Because we should perform powers before products.

solution.p: Each power should be simplified before we compute their product. Because 4 is an even exponent, (-x)^4 is positive, so (-x)^4 = x^4 To simplify (-xy)^3, we apply the fourth law of exponents: (-xy)^3 \amp = (-x)^3y^3 ~~~~\blert{\text{3 is an odd power, so} ~(-x)^3 = -x^3.} \amp = -x^3y^3 Finally, we multiply the powers together to get (-x)^4(-xy)^3 \amp = x^4(-x^3y^3)~~~~\blert{\text{Apply the first law.}} \amp = -x^7y^3

statement.p: In the expression -x^3y^3, does the negtive sign apply to both factors, or only one of them?

introduction.p: Simplify each expression according to the order of operations.
